questions.text: As a radiologist, you are evaluating a male patient who presented with severe hematemesis. Suspecting acute GI bleeding, you performed an endoscopy and a CT angiography, however, both tests were inconclusive. Following that, with the help of a Technetium 99m (99mTc) scintigraphy, you were able to locate the bleeding spot. What level of GI bleeding can be detected by a scintigraphic evaluation?
questions.solution:
A scintigraphic evaluation can detect bleeding rates up to 0.1 to 0.5 mL/min.

Computed Tomography (CT) evaluation is performed in cases of acute gastrointestinal bleeding when endoscopy evaluation is either not clinically feasible or non-diagnostic.

The two CT methods used to evaluate GI bleeding specifically are CT angiography (CTA) and multiphase CT enterography.

CTA can be used to guide both radiological and surgical interventions. it is most useful in an emergency situation to rapidly identify a bleeding source before performing a therapeutic procedure. 
Multiphase CT enterography is typically used to evaluate GI bleeding in stable patients who have negative endoscopy and CTA results.

If the above tests fail, a technetium 99m (99mTc) scintigraphy may be performed which can detect bleeding rates as low as 0.1 to 0.5 mL/min as compared to CT which can detect ranges from 0.5 to 1.0 mL/min. (option A)

questions.text: During the calculation of Well's score in a patient with suspected DVT, the presence of hemoptysis would entail an addition of _____ to the score
questions.solution:
Hemoptysis is given a score of 1 according to the Modified Wells criteria.

Modified Wells criteria for predicting pulmonary embolism:

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Modified Wells criteria:

  • PE likely >4
  • PE unlikely <or =4

In the initial scenario, past history of DVT and positive Moses sign, which is a clinical sign seen in DVT patients, indicating calf pain/tenderness on applying direct pressure over calf muscles as shown below, the Modified Wells score will be (3+1.5= 4.5). 

In the current scenario, the presence of hemoptysis will make the score (4.5+1=5.5). 

Note:

Homans sign - Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with the knee extended will elicit tenderness in the calf. Gentle pressure directly on the calf muscles in the relaxed position will also elicit pain. Care must be taken to be gentle in manipulation lest it may dislodge a clot and cause a pulmonary embolism. The image is attached below. 

Related Pearl: Two-level deep vein thrombosis (DVT) Wells score

Clinical features Points
Active cancer (treatment ongoing within 6 months or palliative) 1
paralysis, paresis, or recent plaster immobilization of the lower extremities  1
Recently bed ridden for 3 days or more or major surgery within 12 weeks requiring general or regional anaesthesia  1
Localised tenderness along the distribution of deep venous system 1
Entire leg swollen 1
calf swelling atleast 3 cm larger than asymptomatic side  1
Pitting edema confined to the symptomatic leg 1
Collateral superficial veins (Non varicose) 1
Previously documented DVT 1
An alternative diagnosis is atleast as likely as DVT -2
Clinical probability simplified score Points
DVT Likely 2 points or more
DVT Unlikely  1 points or less 

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a screening tool to assess the need for medical intervention in a patient with severe hematemesis?
questions.solution:
The Glasgow-Blatchford score is a screening tool used to assess the need for medical intervention such as a blood transfusion or endoscopic intervention in a patient with acute upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding like hematemesis.

It incorporates the patient’s blood urea, haemoglobin, blood pressure, and other clinical parameters.

Other options:

Option B: Rockall score uses clinical variables and findings of initial upper endoscopy to predict the risk of rebleeding and in-hospital mortality in patients with upper GI bleed.

Option C: The Forrest classification is used for classifying the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers. It stratifies the risk of rebleeding based on observed stigmata of recent haemorrhage.

Option D: Agatston score is a CT-based scoring system for reporting the severity of coronary artery calcifications. Cardiovascular mortality and the burden of atherosclerosis have been linked to the presence of coronary artery calcification.

Related Pearl: Glasgow-Blatchford score For UGI bleed

  • Total score ranges from 0 to 23.
  • Hemoglobin value scores differs for men and women.
  • Scores of 6 or more were associated with a greater than 50% risk of needing an intervention.
Factors Value Score

100-109 mmHg

90-99 mmHg

<90 mmHg

1

2

3
Blood urea nitrogen

6.5-7.9 mmol/L

8.0-9.9 mmol/L

10.0-24.9 mmol/L

≥25 mmol/L

2

3

4

6
Haemoglobin for men

12.0-12.9 g/dl

10.0-11.9 g/dL

10.0g/dL

1

3

6
Haemoglobin for women

<10.0-11.9 g/dL

<10.0 g/dL

Pulse ≥100 beats/min

Other variable at presentation

Melena

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with chest pain and hemoptysis following a trematode infection affecting the cystic spaces of the lungs. On further evaluation, peribronchial granulomatous lesions are seen. Which of the following trematodes is responsible for the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 40-year-old male patient, who presented with chest pain and hemoptysis following a trematode infection affecting the cystic spaces of the lungs with the presence of peribronchial granulomatous lesions, is suggestive of infection with Paragonimus westermani (oriental lung fluke).

Adult worms of Paragonimus westermani live in the lungs as pairs in cystic spaces that communicate with bronchi. Their lifespan is up to 20 years in humans. Man is a definitive host. The first intermediate host is a freshwater snail while the second intermediate hosts are freshwater crabs and crayfishes.  

The infective form is metacercariae encysted in crabs and crayfish. Consumption of undercooked crabs and crayfish containing metacercaria is the mode of infection. Patients usually present with cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. Chronic cases resemble pulmonary tuberculosis. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in faeces.

The image below shows the reddish-brown egg-shaped adult worm of Paragonimus westermani.

Inflammatory reactions to the worms and eggs result in peribronchial granulomatous lesions, cystic dilatation of the bronchi and abscesses. Chest X-ray shows nodular, cystic, ring and infiltrative shadows in the middle and lower lobe. 

Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.

The below image shows the lifecycle of Paragonimus westermani.

Other options:

Option B: Clonorchis Sinensis, also known as Chinese liver fluke or oriental liver fluke lives in the biliary tract and pancreatic duct. Metacercaria larvae are the infective form and man acquires infection by consumption of undercooked fish. Initially, patients present with diarrhoea and tender hepatomegaly which is followed by biliary colic and jaundice. Chronic infection is associated with cholangiocarcinoma. It is not associated with pulmonary symptoms as seen in Paragonimus westermani infection.

Option C: Fasciolopsis buski is also known as a giant intestinal fluke. They are the largest trematode infecting humans. Adult worms live in the duodenum or jejunum. Encysted metacercaria is the infective form. Initial symptoms are diarrhoea and abdominal pain followed by partial bowel obstruction.

Option D: Schistosoma mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein and their infective form is fork-tailed cercaria. Following skin penetration by cercariae, a pruritic rash called swimmers itch develops. After 4- 8 weeks they present with a serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever and when the eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop abdominal pain and blood dysentery for a long time called intestinal bilharziasis.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form
Cestode
Diphyllobothrium latum Plerocercoid larva Eggs or segments of the tapeworm
Taenia saginata Cysticercus bovis Egg
Taenia solium Cysticercus cellulosae Egg (for intestinal taeniasis ) / cysticercus cellulosae larva (for cysticercosis)
Echinococcus granulosus Egg Protoscolices and brood capsules
Hymenolepsis nana Egg Egg
Trematode
Schistosoma spp. Cercariae Nonoperculated Eggs
Other trematodes - Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski, Paragonimus westermani, Clonorchis sinensis Metacercaria larva Operculated Eggs
Nematode
Ascaris lumbricoides Egg Unembryonated eggs in stool

Ancylostoma duodenale

Necator americanus

 Filariform larva Eggs (in fresh stool), larva ( in old stool )
Strongyloides stercoralis Filariform larva Rhabditiform larva
Trichuris trichuria Embryonated Egg Unembryonated Egg
Enterobius vermicularis Egg Eggs from perianal skin
Filarial nematodes Third stage Filarial larva (L3) Microfilariae
Trichinella spiralis First stage larva (L1) Trichinella antibody test
Dracunculus medinensis Third stage filariform larva (L3) Adult worm
Hint: The infective and diagnostic forms are usually the same in the parasites causing autoinfection.

Related Pearl: Eggs of Schistosoma

Related Pearl: Lifecycle of Schistosoma

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) was started on a monoclonal antibody that acts by inhibiting VEGF. Within a few months of using this drug, the patient developed severe, life-threatening hemoptysis. Which of the following drugs was likely to have been prescribed to the patient?

VEGF- Vascular endothelial growth factor
questions.solution:
Bevacizumab, an antibody that prevents angiogenesis by binding to the vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), is associated with potentially life-threatening hemoptysis in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients.

It is a humanized monoclonal IgG1 antibody that prevents VEGF from interacting with its receptors on the surface of endothelial cells and inhibits receptor signalling, which normally increases vascular permeability and angiogenesis.

When bevacizumab is combined with paclitaxel and carboplatin for non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), the median survival is increased by approximately two months. A higher risk of pulmonary haemorrhage exists in patients with non-small-cell lung cancer who have cavitary lesions or who have experienced hemoptysis (≥2.5 mL) within the last three months.

Additionally, it slows the advancement of renal cell carcinoma (RCC), metastatic colorectal and ovarian cancer when combined with cytotoxic chemotherapy. 

The adverse effects of bevacizumab include hypertension, thrombosis, proteinuria, and gastrointestinal perforations. Potential vascular damage and bleeding in lung cancer patients is a serious concern. Bevacizumab is contraindicated for patients with a history of hemoptysis, brain metastasis or bleeding diathesis.

Other options:

Option A: Ramucirumab is a human IgG1 monoclonal antibody that targets VEGFR2, preventing VEGFR ligand binding and thereby reducing ligand-induced activity in endothelial cells. It is used in combination with docetaxel to treat patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Adverse effects include hypertension and diarrhoea.

Option C: Aflibercept is a recombinant fusion protein that functions as a VEGF trap by sequestering VEGF using the VEGFR1-binding domain. It is used in treating metastatic colorectal cancer

Option D: Pembrolizumab is a humanized monoclonal IgG4κ isotype antibody that prevents the interaction between programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) and its ligands. It is used in the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, either before or after chemotherapy with platinum. It is also used in the treatment of melanoma, urothelial cancer, Merkel cell carcinoma and Hodgkin lymphoma. Serious adverse events include pneumonitis, colitis and hepatitis.

questions.text: Catamenial hemoptysis is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Catamenial hemoptysis is seen in a condition known as thoracic endometriosis syndrome (TES).

Thoracic endometriosis syndrome (TES) is the result of endometriosis within the lung parenchyma or on the diaphragm and pleural surfaces. This causes a variety of clinical and radiological manifestations, such as catamenial hemoptysis, catamenial pneumothorax, catamenial hemothorax and pulmonary nodules.

Catamenial hemoptysis is characterised by cyclic pulmonary haemorrhage that coincides with the onset of female menstruation.

The mean age of presentation of thoracic endometriosis is  35 years.

Three theories have been put forth to explain the mechanism of thoracic endometriosis These include coelomic metaplasia, retrograde menstruation followed by transperitoneal-trans diaphragmatic migration of endometrial tissue, and lymphatic or hematogenous embolisation from the pelvis or uterus.

The gold standard for a definitive diagnosis of thoracic endometriosis is video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS).

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pseudohemoptysis. He was informed that the color of the sputum is due to a pigment produced by a microorganism. Which of the following pigments is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Pseudohemoptysis is most commonly caused by Serratia marcescens due to the red pigment called prodigiosin.

Serratia marcescens is a pleomorphic coccobacilli. It may grow in sputum after collection. They may mimic hemoptysis (pseudo hemoptysis) because they produce a non-diffusible red pigment called prodigiosin.

S. marcescens contaminate intravenous fluids, surgical instruments, and antiseptic solutions. Therefore, they are one of the important causes of healthcare-associated infections.

Other options:

Pyocyanin(option A) (bluish-green pigment), pyorubin(option B) (red pigment) and pyomelanin(option C) (brown pigment) are pigments produced by Pseudomonas species.

questions.text: A plague epidemic has broken out in a mountainous area. Patients complain of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. On examination, there was no evidence of lymph node involvement. Which of the following modes of transmission is most commonly associated with the type of plague seen in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a plague epidemic where patients present with respiratory symptoms like cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis with no involvement of lymph nodes is suggestive of pneumonic plague. Pneumonic plague most commonly spreads from person to person via droplet infection. 

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. It occurs in 3 clinical forms (in increasing order of severity): bubonic plague< pneumonic plague< septicemic plague

Bubonic plague- It is the most common variety of the disease. It is named after the buboes meaning swollen lymph nodes, which typically develop within a week after an infected flea bite (Xenopsylla cheopis). Other clinical features include sudden onset of fever and chills, headache, and fatigue. Bubonic plague cannot spread from person to person as the bacilli are locked up in the buboes and do not find a way or easy exit.

The images below show a rat flea and bubo formation.

Pneumonic plague- Bubonic plague can advance and spread to the lungs. It is the most virulent/ infectious form of plague. Any person with pneumonic plague may transmit the disease via droplets to other humans. The symptoms include dyspnoea, fever, chest pain, cough, hemoptysis and hemorrhagic pneumonia.  It can also develop from untreated bubonic or septicemic plague through bacteremic spread to the lungs.

Septicemic plague- When the bacteria enter the bloodstream directly and multiply there, it is known as septicemic plague. When left untreated, both bubonic and pneumonic plague can lead to septicemic plague, which is usually fatal. Patients develop fever, chills, extreme weakness, abdominal pain and shock. This form results from bites of infected fleas or from handling an infected animal.

The drug of choice for the treatment of plague is streptomycin. Streptomycin is nephrotoxic and ototoxic and should, therefore be cautiously used. Doxycycline or ciprofloxacin (and other fluoroquinolones) are considered alternative drugs for the treatment of plague.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man awakens in the postanesthesia care unit with paroxysms of coughing and hemoptysis following an uneventful endoscopic sinus surgery. What is the immediate step taken to manage this patient if he is conscious and alert?

choices.text: Raising the head end of the bed

questions.solution:
The immediate step taken to manage a conscious and alert patient experiencing cough and hemoptysis following an uneventful endoscopic sinus surgery is raising the head end of the bed.

Bleeding after nose or throat surgery can be fatal. If the patient is awake and alert enough to cough and swallow without aspirating blood, the first priority should be to stop the bleeding as soon as possible. Immediate measures include raising the head end of the bed to lower the arterial and venous pressures at the bleeding site.

Any level of systolic hypertension should be vigorously treated with intravenous antihypertensive agents. In order to preserve airway reflexes, sedation should be avoided.

If the patient is not fully awake, the secretions may cause the patient to gag and cough, increasing venous pressure and worsening the bleeding. Furthermore, they may aspirate blood and other secretions. In such cases, the patient's airway should be secured immediately by an awake intubation or a rapid-sequence induction (RSI).

The steps of RSI are shown in the image below:

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic, with a history of binge drinking and multiple episodes of intense retching and vomiting, presents with hematemesis prompting suspicion of Mallory-Weiss tear. Which of the following endoscopic findings would be consistent with it?

choices.text: Transmural perforation of the distal esophagus.
Longitudincal mucosal tear near the gastroesophageal junction.
Linear red streaks of dilated venules converging on the antrum
Aberrant vessel in the mucosa that bleeds from a mucosal defect

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with hematemesis following a history of binge drinking and multiple episodes of intense retching and vomiting is suggestive of Mallory-Weiss tear. It occurs due to a longitudinal mucosal tear near the gastroesophageal junction.

It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Management of Mallory Weiss tear

  1. Conservative, as it is usually is self-limiting.
  2. Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy.
  3. Angiographic embolization - if endoscopy fails.
  4. High gastrotomy - if all these manoeuvres fail.

Other options:

Option A: Boerhaave syndrome is characterised by transmural perforation of the distal esophagus (while Mallory-Weiss tear is a mucosal tear). It generally occurs due to forceful vomiting against a closed glottis. It clinically presents with classical Mackler's triad of vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema.

The lower esophagus towards the left pleural cavity is the most common perforation site. A crunching sound is heard during the auscultation of the chest (Hamman's sign) due to subcutaneous emphysema.

Option C: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) is also known as watermelon stomach because of the collection of dilated venules that appear as linear red streaks converging on the antrum. It causes chronic occult blood loss.

Endoscopy reveals longitudinal stripes of edematous erythematous mucosa that alternate with less severely injured, paler mucosa giving the appearance of watermelon.

Management of GAVE

  • Endoscopic argon photocoagulation (APC)
  • If persistent - antrectomy.

Option D: Dieulafoy lesion is an aberrant vessel in the mucosa that bleeds from a mucosal defect. It is a vascular malformation (dilated submucosal arterioles) that is seen along the lesser curvature of the stomach. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Clinical features include sudden onset of massive, painless, recurrent hematemesis with hypotension. Recurrent bleeding with spontaneous cessation is common.

Management of Dieulafoy lesion: 

  • Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy
  • Angiographic embolization.

Related Pearl: Triads in Surgery

Triad

Epigastric pain + Inability to vomit + Inability to pass a nasogastric tube

questions.text: A patient presents with a 4-month history of persistent cough and hemoptysis. Bronchoscopy revealed a mass in the mainstem bronchus. Biopsy shows rosette-like arrangements of tumor cells with uniform round nuclei and moderate amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm. Chromogranin staining was positive. Which of the following factors is responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient who presents with a 4-month history of persistent cough and hemoptysis with a mass in the mainstem bronchus and biopsy showing rosette-like arrangements of tumor cells with uniform round nuclei and moderate amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm with positive chromogranin staining, points towards the diagnosis of bronchial carcinoid tumor. Intraluminal growth of the tumor is the main factor responsible for the above symptoms.

Carcinoid tumors represent 1% to 5% of all lung tumors. Patients present with a persistent cough, hemoptysis, and secondary infections like bronchiectasis and emphysema due to impairment of drainage of respiratory passages.

All these symptoms mainly occur due to intraluminal growth of these lesions. Other factors such as their ability to metastasize, and the ability of some lesions to produce vasoactive amines also contribute to the above symptoms.

The tumor presents as finger-like or spherical polypoid masses that commonly project into the lumen of the bronchus with intact mucosa. It is mostly restricted to the mainstem bronchi whereas other lesions penetrate the bronchial wall and spread out in the peribronchial tissue, resulting in collar-button lesions. 

Carcinoid tumors are low-grade malignant epithelial neoplasms that are subclassified into typical and atypical carcinoids. Typical carcinoids have <2 mitoses per 10 high-power fields (HPF) and lack necrosis; atypical carcinoids have 2-10 mitoses per 10 high-power fields and/or foci of necrosis. Atypical carcinoids also show increased pleomorphism, have more prominent nucleoli, and are more likely to grow in a disorganized fashion and invade lymphatics.

Histologically, it is composed of trabecular, palisading, ribbon, or rosette-like arrangements of cells separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. Tumour cells have uniform round nuclei and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. On electron microscopy, the cells exhibit dense-core neurosecretory granules. Immunohistochemistry is positive for serotonin, neuron-specific enolase, bombesin, and calcitonin.

Other options:

Option A: Lepidic pattern of tumor spread is seen at the periphery of lung adenocarcinomas where the tumor cells tend to crawl along normal-appearing alveolar septa. They vary histologically from well-differentiated tumors with glandular elements, to papillary lesions, to solid masses with only occasional mucin-producing glands and cells.

Option C: The Azzopardi effect is seen in small cell carcinoma which is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to coating by DNA from necrotic tumor cells. It is comprised of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli.

questions.text: A patient bitten by a snake presented with severe swelling of the limb and persistent bleeding from the bite site. He later developed haematuria, gingival bleeding and severe haematemesis. Which of the following family of snakes is responsible for the above manifestations?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient bitten by a snake presenting with severe swelling of the limb and persistent bleeding from the bite site and later developing haematuria, gingival bleeding and severe haematemesis are characteristically seen in the case of Viperidae bite.

Viperidae family consists of snakes that have highly developed long curved, hinged, front fangs, which are channelised in the form of a hypodermic needle. There are two sub families—

  1. Viperinae or true vipers: Saw-scaled Viper and Russell’s Viper
  2. Crotalinae or pit vipers: Rattle snakes and Asian pit vipers.

Viperid bite produces severe local effects. Swelling begins at the bite site and quickly spreads to involve the entire limb. It is associated with pain, tenderness, and regional lymphadenopathy. Blisters appear in and around the bite site in about 12 hours, progressing to involve the entire limb later.

Systemic effects mainly include haemostatic abnormalities. The first evidence of this is persistent bleeding from the bitesite. Within a few hours of the bite, haematuria may appear. Later, gingival bleeding occurs, which is followed by epistaxis, haemoptysis (rarely), and haematemesis. There is also bleeding into the anterior pituitary (causing a Sheehan-like syndrome), subarachnoid haemorrhage, and intracerebral haemorrhage.

Acute renal failure occurs due to widespread microvascular fibrin deposition. Hypotension is a common symptom of all viper bites, and it is usually accompanied by tachycardia.

According to a study on saw-scaled viper bites, haemorrhagic manifestations may be caused by primary pathological fibrinolysis (PPF) rather than disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Certain neurotoxic effects like ptosis and generalised flaccid paralysis may also be seen in the case of Russell’s viper bite.

Other options :

Option A: Bites of Elapidae like Cobras, Common Kraits, Mambas, and Coral Snakes, generally result in neurotoxic effects in the patient. The early symptoms usually include vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, the heaviness of the eyelids, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, hyperacusis, dizziness, and ‘gooseflesh’. Paralysis first presents with ptosis followed by external ophthalmoplegia. Later paralysis of other muscles continues with respiratory paralysis as the end result.

Option C: Colubridae family includes harmless snakes. It includes almost 1400 species of snakes. Most of them have short immobile fangs, or enlarged solid teeth at the posterior end of the maxilla. About one-third of the Colubrid species possess rear fangs which deliver a toxic saliva delivered by a chewing motion. 

Option D: Hydrophidae family comprises sea snakes, which have short fixed fangs as in the case of the elapids. The snake's venom is myotoxic. Some common symptoms include headache, thirst, generalized muscle ache, stiffness, and tenderness, Trismus is an early symptom and is followed by generalized flaccid paralysis similar to elapid neurotoxicity.

Myoglobin released from damaged skeletal muscles causes renal failure and myoglobinuria occurs after a bite, which manifests as the patient passing dark urine.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Snake Toxicity Main features

Viperidae

  • Pit viper
  • Saw-scaled viper
 Vasculotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Severe
    • Edema and necrosis
  • Anticoagulant effect: widespread bleeding

Elapidae

  • Cobra
  • Krait
 Neurotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Mild
  • Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (sea snakes) are now considered a subfamily of Elapidae

 Myotoxic Generalized rhabdomyolysis

Saw scaled viper:

Green pit viper:

Common krait:

King cobra:

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is assumed to be present in any paediatric case presenting with hematemesis and splenomegaly, unless proven otherwise?
questions.solution:
A pediatric case presenting with hematemesis and splenomegaly is presumed to have esophageal variceal bleeding until proven otherwise.

The upper GI endoscopy provides a definitive diagnosis and aids in predicting the risk of bleeding with an option to treat via band ligation or sclerotherapy.

Blood transfusions, vasoactive medications (such as octreotide), short-term antibiotic use, and endoscopy for ligation or sclerotherapy, are all important components of the management of acute variceal bleeding. When variceal bleeding is not responding to medication or endoscopic therapy, a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt should be considered.

Nonselective β blockade and obliteration of varices through repeated ligation or sclerotherapy treatments are used in secondary prophylaxis to lessen bleeding recurrence. 

Prolapse gastropathy secondary to emesis, Mallory-Weiss syndrome and peptic ulcer are all differential diagnoses for gastrointestinal bleeding in childhood.

questions.text: A patient presents with upper abdominal pain, hematemesis and melena following a cholecystectomy procedure. CT angiography reveals bleeding into the biliary tree from an aberrant connection between the bile duct and a blood vessel. Which of the following triads is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with upper abdominal pain, hematemesis and melena due to bleeding into the biliary tree due to an aberrant connection between the bile duct and a blood vessel, points towards the diagnosis of hemobilia. Hemobilia is associated with the Sandblom triad.

Hemobilia is defined as bleeding into the biliary tree from abnormal communication between a blood vessel and the bile duct. Patients often present with a classic triad (Quincke's triad/Sandblom triad) of:

  • Biliary pain
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Gastrointestinal haemorrhage (melena, hematemesis)

The most common cause of hemobilia is iatrogenic trauma to the liver and biliary tree. It can occur due to direct trauma or an arterial pseudoaneurysm following biliary tree exploration surgery, or due to injuries sustained during a cholecystectomy procedure.

Hemobilia caused by accidental abdominal trauma is more common with a blunt injury than a penetrating injury. Primary vascular diseases, such as aneurysms, angiodysplasia, hemangiomas and malignant tumours of the liver are rare causes of hemobilia. 

Investigation of choice: Arterial angiography (CT angiography) is the diagnostic procedure of choice.

Management: Minor hemobilia can be managed conservatively.

Major hemobilia: Transarterial embolization is indicated for major hemobilia requiring blood transfusion. Ligation of the bleeding vessel may also be required.

Other options:

Option A: Charcot triad describes acute cholangitis as clinical findings of fever, right upper abdominal pain, and jaundice.

Option B: Rigler's triad seen in gallstone ileus includes small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia and ectopic gallstone

Option C: Saint's triad includes hiatus hernia, gallstones and colonic diverticulosis

Related Pearl: Triads in Surgery

Galezia's Triad

Hutchison’s teeth (notched upper incisors) + Interstitial keratitis + Nerve deafness

Gallstone ileus

Small bowel obstruction + Pneumobilia + Ectopic gallstone

Saint's Triad

  

Hiatus hernia + Gallstones+ Colonic diverticulosis

Tillaux’s Triad

Mesenteric cyst

Soft fluctuant swelling in umbilical region + Freely mobile perpendicular to mesentery + Zone of resonance all around

Trotter’s Triad

Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

Conductive hearing loss + Immobility of homolateral soft palate + Trigeminal neuralgia

Virchow’s Triad

Thrombosis

Hypercoagulability + Stasis + Endothelial injury

Whipple’s Triad

Insulinoma

Symptoms of hypoglycemia + Serum glucose <50 mg/dL + Symptomatic relief on glucose ingestion

questions.text:
A 54-year-old patient was rushed to the casualty with massive hemoptysis. Which of the following are the indications of urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis?

1. Presence of significant cavitary disease
2. Presence of a fungal ball
3. Presence of a lung abscess
questions.solution:
Indications for urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis are the presence of significant cavitatory disease, a fungal ball, a lung abscess, and failure to control the bleeding. So, option C is the correct answer.

Massive hemoptysis is generally defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-hour period.

Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis:

  • Prevent asphyxiation by achieving respiratory stabilization
  • Localize the bleeding site using flexible/ rigid bronchoscopy 
  • Control the hemorrhage
  • Determine the cause of bleeding
  • Prevent a recurrence

Related Pearl: Types of granulomas

GRANULOMA SEEN IN
Noncaseating granuloma

Crohn’s disease

Leprosy

Sarcoidosis

Hodgkin’s lymphoma
Caseating granuloma

Tuberculosis

Histoplasmosis

Syphilis

Coccidiomycosis
Foreign body granuloma

Silicosis

Berylliosis
Immune granuloma

Wegener’s granulomatosis

Giant cell arteritis
Durck’s granuloma Cerebral malaria
Stellate granuloma Cat scratch disease

questions.text: Hematemesis and melena are the usual presenting features of bleeding located _________
questions.solution:
Hematemesis and melena are the usual presenting features of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Upper GI bleeding is derived from a source proximal to the ligament of Treitz.

The ligament of Treitz is part of the duodenojejunal junction and forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

questions.text: A patient with a history of esophageal varices presents with hematemesis. What is the optimal level of hemoglobin to be maintained in this patient through blood transfusions?
questions.solution:
The optimal level of Hb to be maintained, in this case, is 8 gm/dL.

The indications for blood transfusion are as follows:

  • Acute blood loss: To replace circulating volume and maintain oxygen delivery.
  • Perioperative anemia: To ensure adequate oxygen delivery during the perioperative phase.
  • Symptomatic chronic anemia: without hemorrhage or impending surgery.
Haemoglobin level (g/dL) Indications
<6 Probably will benefit from transfusion
6–8 Transfusion unlikely to be of benefit in the absence of bleeding or impending surgery
>8 No indication for transfusion in the absence of other risk factors

questions.text: An elderly man had an episode of hematemesis. The endoscopy done is given below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the endoscopic image of the patient suggest bleeding esophageal varices. 

Option A: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) is also known as watermelon stomach because of the collection of dilated venules that appear as a linear red streak converging on the antrum. It causes chronic occult blood loss.

The following is an endoscopic image of GAVE:

 

Option C: Hypoproteinemic hypertrophic gastropathy also known as Menetrier's disease is a rare, acquired premalignant disease of the stomach characterized by massive gastric folds, little or no acid production, and excessive mucous production with resultant protein loss. The disorder is associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor alpha.

The following is an endoscopic image of Menetrier's disease:

 

Option D: Dieulafoy's lesion is a vascular malformation that occurs most commonly in the stomach wall. The mucosa covering it can be eroded leading to bleeding from the underlying malformation.

 The following shows an endoscopic image of Dieulafoy's lesion:

questions.text: A patient with hematemesis was brought to the Emergency. His BP was 90/60 mm of Hg and pulse was 110. A gastro-oesophageal bleed is suspected and the given tube is inserted for tamponade. Identify the tube.
questions.solution:
The given tube is a Minnesota tube.

Minnesota tube has 4 openings – 2 suction tubes and 2 inflation tubes. Suction tubes allow aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 3 lumens. It has ports for gastric and esophageal balloons and a gastric aspiration port.

The Minnesota tube or modified-Sengstaken Blakemore tube has an additional oesophageal aspiration port.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old patient on DOTS therapy was rushed to the casualty after having massive hemoptysis. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

DOTS- Directly Observed Therapy Short Course

choices.text: Intubation is done into the non-bleeding lung.
Massive hemoptysis is defined as expectoration of over 750 mL of blood within 24-hours.
Presence of significant cavitary disease is an indication for urgent surgery.
Bleeding is most likely due to pulmonary artery erosion.

questions.solution:
Massive hemoptysis is defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-hour period. Common causes include tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, and cancer. It is a medical emergency.

Any hemoptysis that can cause airway compromise or lead to hemodynamic collapse is called massive hemoptysis. This includes blood loss of >600mL/24h or >150ml/h which can flood the anatomical dead space of the lung.

Bleeding can either be from the bronchial artery circulation (most common) or from the pulmonary artery circulation. Bleeding from cavitary lesions is due to pulmonary artery erosion.

The chest X-ray is the first investigation followed by rigid or flexible bronchoscopy.

The cause of death in massive hemoptysis is usually due to asphyxiation (rather than blood loss itself). This is why airway stabilization by intubating into the non-bleeding lung is the priority. After ventilation is achieved, the bleeding site should be identified using bronchoscopy. Bleeding is controlled by laser, bronchial occlusion, or arterial embolization. Surgical resection of the involved area is also done in some cases.

Indications for urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis:

  • Presence of a fungus ball
  • Presence of a lung abscess
  • Presence of significant cavitary disease
  • Failure to control the bleeding.
